Title: Conditional sentences
References: ALEXANDER, L. G.:  Longman English Grammar. 20th edition.  New York : Longman publishing, 2003. 351 p.
Content:
A condition is something that has to be fulfilled before something else can happen. A condional sentence has 2 basic parts: 

  • A conditional clause (if clause)
  • A main clause 

   A conditional clause states the condition that must be fulfilled before the action of the main clause may be true. It is introduced by: 

- If, As long as, Assuming that, Even if, Given that, If only, On the condition that, Providing that, Suppose

   The two parts of each sentence may be written in reverse order. There is usually no comma after main clause.

   Types of conditional sentences:

  1. Type 0 - If the weather is nice, many people go to the beach.
  2. Type 1 - If the weather is nice, many people will go to the beach.
  3. Type 2 - If the weather was nice, many people would go to the beach.
  4. Type 3 - If the weather had been nice, many people would have gone to the beach.
